Review Emerging two-dimensional metallenes: Recent advances in structural regulations and electrocatalytic applications Jiandong Wu Xiao Zhao * Xiaoqiang Cui # Weitao Zheng # State Key Laboratory of Automotive Simulation and Control, Key Laboratory of Automobile Materials of MOE, School of Materials Science and Engineering, Jilin University, Changchun 130012, Jilin, China State Key Laboratory of Automotive Simulation and Control Key Laboratory of Automobile Materials of MOE School of Materials Science and Engineering Jilin University Changchun Jilin 130012 China State Key Laboratory of Automotive Simulation and Control, Key Laboratory of Automobile Materials of MOE, School of Materials Science and Engineering, Jilin University, Changchun 130012, Jilin, China * Corresponding author # Corresponding author $ Corresponding author Benefiting from the ultrahigh specific surface areas, highly accessible surface atoms, and highly tunable microscopic structures, the two-dimensional metallenes as nanocatalysts have displayed promising performance for various electrocatalytic reactions. Herein, we reviewed recent advances on metallenes in structural regulations including defect, phase, strain, interface, doping, and alloying engineering strategies and their applications in energy electrocatalytic reactions involving oxygen reduction reaction, carbon dioxide reduction reaction, hydrogen evolution reaction, and small molecules oxidation reaction. Finally, we proposed the future challenges and directions in this emerging area. Graphical Abstract In this review, we present the advances on metallenes in their structurally regulating strategies and promising applications in electrocatalysis. Keywords Metallenes Ultrathin nanosheets Structurally regulating strategy Electrocatalysis Enhancement mechanism 1 Introduction Two-dimensional (2D) materials [1–17], have received increasing interest due to their compelling properties including ultrahigh specific surface areas, highly accessible surface atoms, and highly structural tunability. Among them, metallenes, the graphene analogs, is a class of 2D non-layered metal nanomaterials with the thickness typically less than 5 nm, and experience an increasing boom in electrocatalytic applications. For example, as the simplified and well-defined model system, metallenes could serve as the supports to immobilize the single atoms or metal nanoparticles for electrocatalysis applications. However, the advanced strategies remain necessary to engineer metallene's electronic and geometric structures and thus endow improved electrocatalytic performances, ensuring their practical applications. Herein, we reviewed the strategies for structurally engineering of metallenes from defects to phase, strain, interface, doping, and alloying methods that result in electrocatalytically active structures and enhanced intrinsic activity (Fig. 1 ). Thereafter, the application of structurally-tuned metallenes in electrocatalytic reactions is discussed from oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) to carbon dioxide reduction reaction (CO2RR), hydrogen evolution reaction (HER), and small molecules oxidation reaction (SMOR). Finally, we proposed the personal perspectives on remaining opportunities and challenges for this emerging area. 2 Advanced structurally-regulating strategies 2.1 General preparation methods for 2D materials General preparation methods for 2D materials were briefly introduced before discussing structurally-regulating strategies. The thermodynamically unfavorable formation of atomically thin 2D materials is the main challenge in synthesis as the atoms prefer bulk close-packed structures. Fortunately, there are methods including the exfoliation, chemical vapor deposition (CVD), templates, and ligand confinement to prepare 2D materials. Exfoliation of layered bulk materials is a typical approach to prepare single-layer or few-layers 2D materials, however depends on the availability of layered bulk crystals [18]. The CVD is a well-known method to prepare high-quality crystalline 2D materials, however requires gases, substrates, and expensive apparatuses [19]. The templates method using 2D materials (e.g. Ni(OH)2 [20], graphene [21], graphene oxide [22], and LDHs [23]) as the substrates to confine nucleation and guide anisotropic growth is another general strategy for preparing high-quality 2D materials. However, the need to remove templates may cause the destruction of 2D structure and meanwhile complicate the synthesis procedure. The ligand confinement method that utilizes CO [24], amines [6], and halides [25] to limit growth on ligands-adsorbed facets while allow for the growth in the lateral directions is often adopted for 2D materials. The ligands play dual roles in nuclei-growth kinetics of 2D materials via modulating redox potentials of metal ions and reducing the surface energy of 2D materials. Hereafter, the strategies to optimize electrocatalytically active structures were discussed in terms of defects, phases, strain, interfaces, doping, and alloying engineering. Notably, the metallene electrocatalysts generally combine several engineering strategies to maximize catalysis efficiency; thereby for clarity, we may highlight the most unique strategies in an electrocatalyst. 2.2 Defect engineering Defects mean the imperfection relative to an ideal periodical crystal. According to the dimensions, defects can be classified into point defects (e.g. vacancies and heteroatoms), line defects (e.g. dislocations and screws), planar defects (e.g. twins and grain boundaries), and bulk defects (e.g. voids and hollows) [26,27]. Defects affect electrocatalytic performance through either directly acting as active sites [28] and/or tuning electronic and coordination structures of active sites [29,30], and/or cooperatively promoting electrocatalytic process (e.g. the synergy effect) [31,32], and/or producing newly-exposed surfaces (e.g. pore inner surface). Li et al. [33] synthesized RuO2 nanosheets (NSs) with an averaging thickness of 1.6 nm and sizes up to several microns by a facile molten salt method (Figs. 2(a), (b) ). The abundant multi-scale defects including Ru vacancies, dislocations, and grain boundaries exist in RuO2 NSs (Figs. 2(c) and (d)). For enhanced oxygen evolution reaction (OER) performance on RuO2 NSs, density functional theory calculations suggest that Ru vacancies significantly weakens the binding energy of O* with respect to that of OOH*, decreasing the energy cost for the transformation from O* to OOH* [33]. The 1.2 nm-thin PtTe2 NSs synthesized by an electrochemically exfoliating method show corrugated and roughened surfaces rich with ordered Te vacancies (Figs. 2(e)–(h)), in which those defects enhanced HER kinetics by optimizing adsorption energy of hydrogen [18]. Pores often expose newly active surfaces and simultaneously facilitate mass transfer, both of which benefit electrocatalytic process. However, the synthesis of porous metallenes is not an easy task. In this regard, porous Pd metallenes [34] (Figs. 2(i)–(l)) and the perforated Pd NSs [35] (Figs. 2(m) and (n)) were prepared recently by an one-pot wet-chemical method. Additionally, the holey Pd NSs [36] were fabricated by the Br–/O2 pairs oxidative etching of Pd NSs under ambient conditions. The Pd3Pb ultrathin porous intermetallic nanosheets (UPINs, Figs. 2(o) and (p)) were synthesized by a two-steps template-directed strategy, in which the migration of Pd triggered emergence of Pd3Pb UPINs due to the Pb atoms altering the thermodynamic state of initial Pd NSs [37]. 2.3 Phase engineering Phase engineering could induce beneficially electrocatalytic structures via differentiating atomic arrangement from conventional thermodynamically-stable phases and usually involve the production of unconventional crystalline phases, amorphous phases, and heterophases. However, it remains challenging to develop unconventional crystalline phases due to their higher system energy relative to thermodynamically-stable ones. Nevertheless, the metallenes owing to their surface energy dominating the total system energy have the chances to display unconventional phases and simultaneously keep stable under ambient conditions [38,39]. Huang et al. [22] synthesized Au square NSs with hexagonal close-packed (hcp) phase on graphene oxide templates via the wet-chemical reduction (Figs. 3(a)–(d) ). Interestingly, the phase transformation from hcp to face-centered cubic (fcc) occurred when Au NSs are exposed under the electron-beam irradiation. Face-centered tetragonal (fct) Pd-based alloy NSs (PdCd, PdZn, and PdZnCd) were also prepared by the one-pot wet-chemical route [40]. Amorphous materials are long-range disordered and possess superior elastic strain performance relative to their crystalline counterparts [41]. More importantly, amorphous materials possess rich unsaturated surface sites and structural defects that bring opportunities to tune local electronic structures of electrocatalysts. However, metal materials are usually crystalline because of the strong and isotropic trait of metallic bonds, challenging preparation of amorphous metal materials. Via annealing metal acetylacetonates with alkali salts, the amorphous Ir, Rh, Ru, RhFe, IrRu, and IrRhRu NSs (Figs. 3(e) and (f)) were synthesized recently. The superior OER activity on amorphous Ir NSs over crystalline Ir NSs and commercial IrO2 catalyst was attributed to abundant active sites and the unique atomic structure of amorphous Ir NSs [42]. Zhang et al. [43] presented a ligand-induced amorphization synthesis method, in which a unique bismuthiol molecule induces the transformation of Pd nanomaterials from fcc phase into the amorphous phase without destroying their integrity. Heterophases consist of two or more different phases and their interfaces in individual particles. These phase boundaries are expected capable to combine two or more different functions and induce the cooperating effects between neighboring phase sites, which is especially valuable for improving electrocatalytic activity and selectivity [44–49]. Zhang et al. [47] reported the synthesis of Pd NSs with amorphous/crystalline heterophases, evidenced by the co-existence of amorphous and crystalline domains seen from microscope images and SAED patterns (Figs. 3(g)–(k)) and extend synthesis of heterophase PdCu NSs (Figs. 3(l)–(o)) [48]. By simply tailoring synthetic temperature, Rh, RhCu, RhZn, and RhRu NSs with amorphous/crystalline heterophase were also successfully synthesized [49]. 2.4 Strain engineering Strain engineering is a general method to tailor d-band centers of metals, which may arise from the interfacial lattice mismatch, structural defects, shape/geometric regulation, alloying effect, and their combinations. Strain effect possessing the long-range attribute [50,51] in comparison with ligand effect (about 1–2 monolayers away from the surface) [52,53] is an unique merit and means more surface atoms that are tuned and available for electrocatalysis. Indeed, the stain engineering has been widely applied in tuning 2D materials. For instance, Luo et al. [9] reported the synthesis of highly-curved sub-nanometer PdMo@Pd bimetallene (Figs. 4(a)–(d) ), where Mo atoms induces an average tensile strain of 0.95% compared to unstrained Pd metallenes. The interfacial lattice mismatch in PtPb core@Pt shell-structured nanoplates generates a unique facet-dependent biaxial tensile strain that accelerates oxygen reduction kinetics greatly (Figs. 4(e)–(g)) [54]. Notably, different from the doping and alloying effects, the strain engineering do not necessarily require adding second elements and can be simply achieved by a purely structural regulation. For example, the surface stains of Pd metallenes were tuned only by changing metallenes thickness. Specifically, the regulation of metallenes thicknesses from 3 to 5 and 8 monolayers achieved intrinsically-compressive strains in Pd NSs from 1.5% to 1.2% and 0.3%, respectively, compared to bulk Pd (Figs. 4(h)–(o)) [55]. This thickness-dependent intrinsic strain (strains increase when thicknesses decrease) is speculated to be universal for 2D metallenes. On the operation mechanism of strain engineering, the general guideline is that the strain tunes reactivity of metal surfaces by upshifting or downshifting d bands to strengthen or weaken adsorption energies of intermediates, respectively, thereby tuning reaction kinetics. However, whether reaction kinetics are promoted or inhibited is determined together by the types of strains (tensile or compressive strain), catalytic metals (early or late transition metals), and reactions (e.g. ORR and FAOR). In more detail, the tensile strain narrowing d bands and to preserve the degree of d-band filling will downshift d bands of early transition metals while upshift d bands of late transition metals, vice versa. Further, the reaction types matter. For example, the oxygen binding energy on Pt is a bit stronger than the optimal value; thereby, a compressive strain induces the downshifted d band that weakens oxygen binding and promotes ORR kinetic on Pt. The first-principles theory predicted that the compressive strains can lower the reaction overpotential to boost the formate pathway and alleviate CO poisoning on the Pt surface, while tensile strains should have the opposite effects [56]. However, interestingly, Jin et al. [57] revealed that in a wide strain range from −5.1% to 5.9%, the relationships between the surface strain of platinum and the electroactivity for the methanol oxidation reaction (MOR) and HER follow an M-shaped curve and a volcano-shaped curve, respectively. For MOR, the rate-determining step is the removal of poisoning CO-like intermediates via the reaction (CO* + OH* = CO2 + H+ + e−) which is determined jointly by the water disassociation to produce OH* and the adsorption strength of CO*. The tensile-strained Pt surface benefits the removal of surface-bound CO* by increasing OH* production as increasing tensile strain facilitates water dissociation and strengthens adsorption of OH* and H* in both acidic and alkaline solutions. Meanwhile, a compressive strain weakens the adsorption energy of CO*, which promotes the removal of CO* and enhance MOR, a opposite trend for OH* descriptor. Together, the moderate tensile (< 4.7%) and compressive (< 3.9%) strains both boost MOR on Pt by producing rich OH* species and weakening CO* adsorption energy, respectively, consequently resulting in a M-shaped curve between the surface strain and MOR kinetics. Those representative examples highlight the complex relationship between lattice strains and specific reaction kinetics [57]. 2.5 Interface engineering The interfaces are the boundaries or region across two or more phases. Electrocatalysts generally involve metal-carbon, metal-metal, and metal-oxide interfaces, in which, the interfacial lattice mismatch, the interfacial charge transfer, and the interfacial cooperation between different interfacial sites may tune electrocatalytic processes via changed electronic structures and the bifunctional mechanism. On the other hand, the introduction of interfaces in electrocatalysts challenges the revelation of active phases and enhancement mechanisms. Thus, the identification and maximization of electrocatalytically active interfaces are crucial for interface engineering. In this regard, atomically-dispersed interfaces could maximize interfacial effects through downsizing catalytic metal from the nanoscale to the atomic level. For example, atomically dispersed RuO x -on-Pd NSs where oxidized Ru single atoms are on Pd NSs show the capacity to amplify interfacial effect and thus endow RuO x -on-Pd NSs with particularly high oxygen reduction performance (Figs. 5(a)–(e) ) [58]. Revealed by density functional theory calculations, the charge can transfer from 2D Pd host to RuO x /Pd interfaces and subtly change the adsorption configuration of O2 to facilitate the O−O bond cleavage. Meanwhile, RuO x /Pd interfaces downshifted d-band center of Pd and consequently weaken oxygen binding strength on Pd [58]. Instead of conventional metal/oxide interfaces, the inversely structured oxide/metal interfaces indeed received increasing attention, in which the metals as supports show better conductivity and simultaneously promote charge transfer, both of which benefit electrocatalysis [59]. For example, SnO2 nanoparticles dispersed on Pd NSs to generate SnO2/Pd NSs were shown with abundant Pd–O–Sn interfaces for high-efficiency CO2 electroreduction (Figs. 5(f) and (g)) [60]. Changing interfacial components and structures induces synergistic effects between interfacial phases and/or modify the electronic and geometric structures of interfacial metals, which thus provide a large room for interface engineering. Rh-SnO2 interfaces in SnO2/Rh NSs were reported displaying a strong synergy to significantly promote breaking C–C of C2H5OH and facilitate oxidation of poisonous intermediates (*CO and *CH3), consequently resulting in enhanced electrocatalytic performances (Figs. 5(h)–(j)) [61]. 2.6 Doping and alloying effect Doping, the incorporation of trace second or more elements into host lattices to tailor electronic structures of the hosts, is the most used method for electrocatalysts to regulate their electronic and geometric structures [62]. Generally, the doping elements can permeate into interstitial positions or replace host atoms. Light atoms, such as H [63–66] and B [67], tend to enter into interstitial sites owing to their small atomic radius. Recently, we reported hydrogen stabilized RhPdH NSs for efficient alkaline hydrogen evolution [68]. The RhPdH NSs with an averaging thickness of 1.8 nm show roughly flat surfaces and some wrinkles (Figs. 6(a) and (b) ). The interstitial hydrogen in RhPdH NSs resulted in about 3.6% expanded lattices compared to the normal RhPd alloy (Figs. 6(c) and (d)), which optimized adsorption energy of H on RhPdH NSs for a accelerated alkaline HER. We also synthesized MoPdH NSs with an averaging thickness of about 2.7 nm via a one-pot wet chemical approach (Figs. 6(e) and (f)) [69]. The chemical analysis by electron-energy-loss spectra (EELS, Figs. 6(g) and (h)) revealed the hydrides characteristic as evidenced from a negative shift of about 2 eV at low-energy region for MoPdH NSs compared with that of MoPd NSs. The interstitial H boosts the CO-tolerance in MOR by weakening CO* adsorption strength on MoPdH NSs [69]. On the other hand, dopants can enter lattice positions by replacing host atoms. For example, Mao et al. [70] synthesized Co-substituted Ru NSs that have an averaging thickness of about 1.6 nm and display (0001) basal plane, (011(-)0) side plane, and uniform distribution of Co and Ru elements. Increasing the ratio of dopants to form alloy is one of the most used methods in materials science. For example, PdIr alloying NSs (Figs. 6(m)–(p)) were prepared for hydrogen evolution and formic acid oxidation and showed the curved morphology, ultrathin characteristic (five atomic layers), and (111) facets in the vertical direction [71]. Similarly, PdCu [72,73], PtCu [74], RhW [75], RhRu [76], PtPtAg [77] were also studied for varied electrocatalytic reactions. Multi-components doping and alloying strategies may provide new opportunities for optimizing electronic structures of electrocatalysts and shifting reaction pathways, however is beyond the scope of this review. 3 Electrochemical applications of metallenes Benefiting from the ultrahigh specific surface areas, highly accessible surface atoms, and highly tunable structures, the metallenes are promising nanocatalysts for electrochemical reactions. Indeed, structurally-engineered metallenes have made great advances in electrocatalytic applications, such as ORR, CO2RR, HER, MOR, FAOR and ethanol oxidation reaction (EOR). We summarized representative examples in Table 1 and selectively discussed them in the following sections. 3.1 The metallenes for the ORR The ORR is the cathodic reaction of fuel cells and metal-air batteries, however, suffers from sluggish kinetics, thereby requiring efficient ORR catalysts to reduce overpotentials and thus improve energy efficiency. For the design or the prediction of efficient catalysts, the Sabatier principle states that the binding energy of reactants/intermediates on catalysts should be neither too strong nor too weak [88]. Thus, the binding energy calculated from the density functional theory and determined by the electronic structure of catalysts can be used as a quantitative descriptor for searching potential electrocatalysts. Notably, the interfacial electric field and the interfacial solvation effect have demonstrated non-negligible influence on electrocatalytic reaction kinetics and needs to be considered for designing catalysts. There are diverse strategies to regulate electronic structures of catalysts and often involve ligand effect, charge transfer, geometric effect, lattice strain, and their combinations. The structural advantage of metallenes for the ORR can be exemplified by that Pd metallenes delivered superior ORR activity and catalytic stability compared with a benchmark commercial Pt/C (Figs. 7(a)–(d) ) [34]. Expectedly, the structurally-engineering strategies would endow metallenes with further improvement in electrocatalysis performances. Representatively, PdMo bimetallenes exhibited the 78-fold and 327-fold enhancement in mass activity for the alkaline ORR relative to commercial Pt/C and Pd/C catalysts, respectively, simultaneously with a robust stability (Figs. 7(e)–(h)). The significantly enhanced performance was ascribed to the multi-engineering strategies including the alloying effect, the strain effect from the curved geometry, and the quantum effect from ultrathin sheet-like morphology, which together optimized oxygen binding energy on PdMo bimetallenes [9]. The atomic dispersion of RuO x on Pd metallenes (RuO x -on-Pd) to construct oxide/metal inverse interfaces in contrast with the conventional metal/oxides interfaces was claimed to optimize both the supports conductivity and the interfacial effect. The resultant RuO x -on-Pd displayed superior ORR activity and kept stable during 20000 potential cycles, which was ascribed to the promoted interfacial charge transfer and the facilitated O–O bond cleavage at the oxide/metal inverse interfaces (Figs. 7(i)–(l)) [58]. 3.2 The metallenes for the CO2RR The CO2RR driven by electricity is promising to simultaneously address global energy and environmental challenges. However, the CO2RR suffers from sluggish kinetics and the competitive HER, thereby demanding highly efficient and selective CO2RR electrocatalysts. In this regard, the metallenes-based materials are promising candidates. Typically, the partially oxidized 4-atoms-thick Co NSs synthesized by a ligand-confined growth strategy has exhibited encouraging CO2RR performance with respect to a large overall current density and the highest Faradaic efficiency for the formate product, and the negligible decay in a durability test, as compared with bulk and metallic metallenes counterparts (Figs. 8(a)–(d) ), in which oxidized Co atoms are indispensable for superior CO2RR performance [6]. The Pd is known to selectively reduce CO2 to CO or formate, however, the CO2RR performances on Pd metallenes are size dependent and change with their edge length (Figs. 8(e)–(h)) [89]. Recently, bismuthene exhibited unexpected CO2RR performance with a small onset overpotential (< 90 mV vs. RHE), high Faradaic efficiency (99% at −580 mV vs. RHE), superior Tafel slope value (87.6 mV dec–1), and excellent durability (> 75 h) (Figs. 8(i)–(l)) [78]. Mechanistic studies showed that the intrinsically compressive strain on atomically-thin bismuthenes benefits the CO2RR. 3.3 The metallenes for the HER Electrolyzing water by renewable energy to provide ‘green’ hydrogen is becoming an important part of a hydrogen economy. Improving energy efficiency and making ‘green’ hydrogen cost-competitive with hydrogen generated from fossil fuels strongly depend on high-performance HER electrocatalysts. Recently, we developed RhPdH bimetallenes under the guidance of the Miedema rule. The obtained RhPdH bimetallenes possessed ultrahigh HER activity and stability, in which the confined interstitial hydrogen atoms as a unique structural regulator were indispensable (Figs. 9(a)–(f) ) [68]. Moreover, PdIr bimetallenes [71], single-atom Co-substituted Ru metallenes [70], and PtTe2 with Te vacancies [18] were also highly efficient for the HER. 3.4 The metallenes for the SMOR Liquid small molecules are easy to store and transport relative to hydrogen fuel and compatible with current infrastructure. In this context, direct liquid fuel cells have their unique advantages and attracted considerable attention [90–94]. However, the anodic oxidation of liquid fuels such as MOR, EOR, and FAOR are very sluggish and require large overpotentials, which limits the energy efficiency and power density. Anodic electrocatalysts are necessary but often poisoned by the CO-like intermediates in the SMOR, thereby necessitating the poisoning-tolerant electrocatalysts. We recently synthesized ultrathin molybdenum-palladium hydride bimetallenes via the MoPd alloying to stabilize H. This MoPdH bimetallenes showed a high CO-tolerance, 6.0-fold enhancement in mass activity, and long-term stability relative to commercial Pd black, representing a kind of effective poisoning-tolerant MOR electrocatalysts (Figs. 10(a) and (b) ) [69]. Recently, Zhang et al. [40] reported a series of PdM (M = Zn, Cd, ZnCd) NSs with the thickness less than 5 nm. Different from the conventional fcc phase, these PdM NSs possessed an unconventional fct phase and exhibited significantly enhanced mass activity and stability for the EOR compared to pure Pd NSs and commercial Pd black (Figs. 10(c) and (d)). The ultrathin PdCu NSs treated by ethylenediamine displayed an excellent poisoning-tolerance to CO-like intermediates during FAOR (Figs. 10(e) and (f)) [73]. These examples strongly suggest that the combination of metallenes with alloying effect may open up new opportunities for developing highly-efficiency and poisoning-tolerant anodic electrocatalysts for direct liquid fuel cells. 4 Conclusion and perspectives Recent progress on 2D metallenes was reviewed with respect to structurally-engineering strategies (defects, phases, strain, interfaces, doping, and alloying strategies) and electrocatalysis applications (ORR, CO2RR, HER, and SMOR). Despite the great advances made in metallenes, challenges remain for their practical applications in electrocatalysis and include but are not limited to the theory-guided design of metallenes-based electrocatalysts, the identification of active sites and enhancement mechanisms, the universal and large-scale synthesis of metallenes, and the evaluation of metallenes in practical devices (Fig. 11 ). Notably, these challenges are interrelated strongly and the applications of metallenes in practical devices depend on the comprehensive efforts undoubtedly. We herein discussed these challenges and the possible solutions. (1) The theory-guided design of active metallenes-based electrocatalysts: the trial-and-error method is the most used research paradigm for developing new catalysts however limits the efficiency seriously, which pressingly calls for the theory-guided rational design of high-performance catalysts. The new design concepts and principles are always desirable for the electrocatalysis community and actually have made great progress, such as the Sabatier principle, d-band theory, scaling relationships, and reactivity descriptors. Fortunately, the advances in computing science provides new tools, for example, machine learning and data mining to enable property prediction and structure screening more efficiently relative to the conventional methods for a rational design of metallenes catalysts. However, the calculations/simulations at affordable cost and really representing real-word-catalysis are still under the way. (2) The identification of active sites and enhancement mechanisms: these information are fundamentally important for the rational design of high-performance electrocatalysts; however, active sites in heterogeneous electrocatalysts are often multiple and dynamically reconstructive under electrocatalysis conditions, challenging the revelation of realistic active sites and associated enhancement mechanisms. Moreover, the structural reconstruction is complicated and may involve phase transformation, morphology evolution, valence changes, and local coordination environment changes, and so on. Thus, in-situ and/or operando monitoring of the dynamically-structural evolution and the electrocatalysis processes are necessary and require developing new characterization techniques. (3) The universal and large-scale synthesis of metallenes is the premise for the realistic application of metallenes electrocatalysts, however, only limited synthesis strategies are currently available and dependent on surfactants and/or capping molecules to control thickness, sizes, and crystal phases of metallenes. The surfactants and/or capping agents may partially hinder active sites and are undesirable for electrocatalysis. The synthesis using the removal structure-directing agents to fully expose active sites is promising for the scalable synthesis of metallenes and their practical applications. (4) The evaluation of metallenes in practical devices would tell us which kinds of structural metallenes are suitable for the real-world application; however, the most of current applications are still limited to the half-cell test, which may neglect some structural requirements for practice devices, for example, the effective mass transfer at high current densities. Taking the application of ORR electrocatalysts in hydrogen fuel cells as an example, the practical electrocatalysts need the integration of rational pore structures, high intrinsic activity, high density of active sites, and high resistance for electrochemical corrosion. Thereby a systemic consideration and design are necessary for the application of metallenes in practical devices. (5) Orienting the potential new application: in addition to these electrocatalysis applications, the metallenes also show the promising applications in organic reactions and photothermal therapy. Organic reactions normally suffer from the inferior catalytic activity and selectivity towards the target product, similarly, there is still a long way to go for designing favourable targeting, stability and biocompatibility photothermal therapy agents for the medical field. coredata.dc:description: Benefiting from the ultrahigh specific surface areas, highly accessible surface atoms, and highly tunable microscopic structures, the two-dimensional metallenes as nanocatalysts have displayed promising performance for various electrocatalytic reactions. Herein, we reviewed recent advances on metallenes in structural regulations including defect, phase, strain, interface, doping, and alloying engineering strategies and their applications in energy electrocatalytic reactions involving oxygen reduction reaction, carbon dioxide reduction reaction, hydrogen evolution reaction, and small molecules oxidation reaction. Finally, we proposed the future challenges and directions in this emerging area.
coredata.prism:publisher: Dalian Institute of Chemical Physics, the Chinese Academy of Sciences. Published by Elsevier B.V.
coredata.dc:title: Emerging two-dimensional metallenes: Recent advances in structural regulations and electrocatalytic applications
